question: The relative price of a good is all of the following except

options.answer: the ratio of one price to another.
an opportunity cost.
the money price of the good divided by a price index.
the same as the money price of a good.
determined in a market.

question: How many sides does a market have?

options.answer: one side - buyers
one side - sellers
two sides - buyers and sellers
three sides - buyers, sellers, and the government
two sides - domestic and foreign

question: Which market is an example of a market for goods?

options.answer: labour market
haircut market
manufactured input market
apple market
energy market

question: Which market is an example of a market for services?

options.answer: orange market
tennis lessons market
manufactured input market
energy market
labour market

question: Which market is an example of a resource market?

options.answer: furniture market
apple market
automobile market
haircut market
labour market

question: The demand and supply model determines

options.answer: relative prices.
money prices.
supply prices.
demand prices.
absolute prices.

question: Refer to Table 3.1.1. In 2010, the relative price of coffee in terms of tea is
Refer to Table 3.1.1. In 2012, the relative price of coffee in terms of cola is

options.answer: unknown without more information.

question: Refer to Table 3.1.1. In 2012, the relative price of cola in terms of tea is

options.answer: unknown without more information.

question: Refer to Table 3.1.1. Between 2010 and 2011, the price of coffee relative to the price of tea ________ while the price of coffee relative to the price of cola ________.

options.answer: rose; rose
rose; fell
fell; rose
fell; fell
fell; stayed constant

question: Refer to Table 3.1.1. Between 2011 and 2012, the price of coffee relative to the price of tea ________ while the price of coffee relative to the price of cola ________.

options.answer: rose; rose
rose; fell
fell; rose
fell; fell
fell; stayed constant

question: A market where no single buyer or seller can influence the price is

options.answer: a buyer's market.
a seller's market.
a competitive market.
an output market.
an input market.

question: A relative price is

options.answer: the ratio of one price to another.
an opportunity cost.
a quantity of a "basket" of goods and services forgone.
determined by demand and supply.
all of the above.

question:
William Gregg owned a mill in South Carolina. In December 1862, he placed a notice in the Edgehill Advertister announcing his willingness to exchange cloth for food and other items. Here is an extract:

1 yard of cloth for 1 pound of bacon
2 yards of cloth for 1 pound of butter
4 yards of cloth for 1 pound of wool
8 yards of cloth for 1 bushel of salt

If the money price of bacon was 20Â¢ a pound and the money price of salt was $2.00 a bushel, people would ________.

options.answer: buy bacon and trade it for cloth because they could buy 8 yards of cloth for only $1.60, and use that cloth to obtain a bushel of salt
not buy bacon and trade it for cloth because they would have to buy 8 yards of cloth for $1.60 and then give Mr. Gregg an extra $0.40 to buy a bushel of salt
buy bacon and trade it for cloth and then trade the cloth for salt because salt is more important for life than either cloth or bacon
not buy bacon and trade it for cloth because the relative price of 1 bushel of salt is only 1/8 yard of cloth
buy bacon and trade it for cloth because cloth is more expensive than bacon

question: The opportunity cost of good A in terms of good B is equal to the

options.answer: money price of good A minus the money price of good B.
money price of good B minus the money price of good A.
ratio of the money price of good A to the money price of good B.
ratio of the money price of good B to the money price of good A.
money price of good A plus the money price of good B.

question: Suppose the price of a football is $20.00 and the price of a basketball is $10.00. The ________ of a football is ________.

options.answer: relative price; 2 basketballs per football
relative price; 1/2 basketball per football
opportunity cost; $15.00
opportunity cost; $10.00
relative price; $10

question: The law of demand states that, other things remaining the same,

options.answer: the higher the price of a good, the smaller is the quantity demanded.
the higher the price of a good, the smaller is the quantity supplied.
price and quantity supplied are positively related.
as income increases, willingness to pay for the last unit increases.
the higher the price of a good, the greater is the quantity demanded.

question: Which one of the following events shifts the demand curve for grape jelly to the right?

options.answer: an increase in income if grape jelly is a normal good
a decrease in the price of strawberry preserves, a substitute for grape jelly
a decrease in the price of grape jelly
an increase in the price of peanut butter, a complement of grape jelly
a decrease in the population

question: The demand curve slopes downward to the right because

options.answer: an increase in income leads to increased consumption.
of the law of supply.
of the law of demand.
of comparative advantage.
as income rises, the quantity demanded increases.

question: An increase in the price of ground beef

options.answer: increases the demand for chicken, a substitute for ground beef.
increases the demand for hamburger buns, a complement of ground beef.
increases the quantity demanded of ground beef.
decreases the quantity demanded of ground beef.
both A and D.

question: An increase in income

options.answer: increases the demand for turnips if a turnip is an inferior good.
increases the demand for turnips if a turnip is a normal good.
increases the supply of turnips.
decreases the demand for turnips if turnips have a very low price.
decreases the supply of turnips.

question: A turnip is an inferior good if

options.answer: an increase in the price of a turnip decreases the quantity of turnips that consumers want to buy.
an increase in income decreases the demand for turnips.
an increase in income increases the demand for turnips.
turnips violate the law of demand.
turnips are a low quality good.

question: If a turnip is an inferior good, then, ceteris paribus, an increase in the price of a turnip will

options.answer: decrease the demand for turnips.
increase the demand for turnips.
decrease the supply of turnips.
increase the supply of turnips.
none of the above.

question: Suppose income increases.  Choose the correct statement.

options.answer: The equilibrium price of turnips falls if a turnip is an inferior good.
The equilibrium price of turnips rises if a turnip is an inferior good.
The equilibrium quantity of turnips decreases if a turnip is an inferior good.
The supply of turnips decreases whether or not a turnip is an inferior good.
Both A and C.

question: Point A in Figure 3.2.1 indicates that

options.answer: $1 is the least that consumers are willing to pay for the 4,000th apple.
consumers will not be in equilibrium if the price of an apple is $1.
consumers will only pay $1 for any apple.
if the price is $1, consumers will plan to buy 4,000 apples.
if the price is more than $1, consumers will buy 9,000 apples.

question: Which one of the following statements best characterizes point B in Figure 3.2.1?

options.answer: Producers would be unwilling to sell the 9,000th apple for less than $0.50.
The most that consumers would be willing to pay for the 9,000th apple is $0.50.
At a price of $0.50, consumers will be unwilling to buy any apples.
At a price of $0.50, there will be an apple shortage.
At point B, the market is in equilibrium.

question: Given Figure 3.2.1, under what condition are consumers willing to buy more than 9,000 apples per week?

options.answer: if the price is above $1
if the price is between $1 and $0.50
if the price is below $0.50
if the price is between $1 and $1.50
if the price is $0.75

question: Which one of the following would result in a movement from point A to point B in Figure 3.2.1?

options.answer: a fall in the price of apples
a rise in the price of oranges
an increase in population size
public concern about chemicals sprayed on apples
a rise in the price of bananas

question: Which one of the following would result in the demand curve shifting from D1 to D2 in Figure 3.2.2?

options.answer: an increase in the supply of pizza
a rise in the price of hamburgers, a substitute for pizza
a rise in the price of pizza
a fall in the price of pizza
a rise in the price of Coke, a complement of pizza

question: Refer to Figure 3.2.2. Which one of the following represents a decrease in quantity demanded?

options.answer: a shift from D1 to D2
a shift from D2 to D1
a movement from A to B
a movement from B to A
none of the above

question: Refer to Figure 3.2.2. If consumers' income increases,

options.answer: the quantity of pizzas demanded increases.
the demand curve for pizzas shifts from D1 to D2 if a pizza is a normal good.
the supply of pizzas increases.
the quantity of pizzas supplied decreases.
a movement from point A to point B on D1 occurs.

question: The price of good A rises, and the demand curve for good B shifts leftward. We can conclude that

options.answer: A and B are substitutes.
A and B are complements.
A and B are complements in production.
B is an inferior good.
B is a normal good.

question: The price of good X falls and the demand for good Y decreases.  We can conclude that

options.answer: X and Y are complements.
X and Y are independent of each other.
X is an inferior good.
X is a normal good.
X and Y are substitutes.

question: Which one of the following would lead to an increase in the demand for hamburgers?

options.answer: a new fad hamburger diet
a decrease in population size
a rise in the price of French fries, a complement of hamburgers
a decrease in consumer income if hamburgers are a normal good
a news report that hamburgers can cause skin diseases

question: Which of the following "other things" are not held constant along a demand curve?

options.answer: income
prices of related goods
the price of the good itself
preferences
expected future income and credit

question: Good A is a normal good if

options.answer: a rise in the price of a complement causes the demand for A to decrease.
income and the demand for A are negatively related.
a rise in the price of a substitute causes the demand for A to increase.
the demand for A increases when income rises.
good A satisfies the law of demand.

question: A decrease in quantity demanded is represented by a

options.answer: rightward shift of the supply curve.
rightward shift of the demand curve.
leftward shift of the demand curve.
movement upward and to the left along the demand curve.
movement downward and to the right along the demand curve.

question: Some sales managers are talking shop. Which of the following quotations refers to a movement along the demand curve?

options.answer: "Since our competitors raised their prices, our sales have doubled."
"It has been an unusually mild winter; our sales of wool scarves are down from last year."
"We decided to cut our prices, and the increase in our sales has been remarkable."
"The Green movement has sparked an increase in our sales of biodegradable products."
None of the above.

question: Some sales managers are talking shop. Which one of the following quotations refers to a rightward shift of the demand curve?

options.answer: "Since our competitors raised their prices, our sales have doubled."
"It has been an unusually harsh winter; our sales of wool scarves are up from last year."
"We decided to cut our prices, and the increase in our sales has been remarkable."
"The Green movement has sparked an increase in our sales of biodegradable products."
All of the above except C.

question: Some sales managers are talking shop. Which one of the following quotations refers to a leftward shift of the demand curve?

options.answer: "Since our competitors raised their prices, our sales have doubled."
"It has been an unusually mild winter; our sales of wool scarves are down from last year."
"We decided to cut our prices, and the increase in our sales has been remarkable."
"The Green movement has sparked an increase in our sales of biodegradable products."
None of the above.

question: If Hamburger Helper is an inferior good, then, ceteris paribus, a decrease in income will lead to

options.answer: a leftward shift of the demand curve for Hamburger Helper.
a rightward shift of the demand curve for Hamburger Helper.
a movement up along the demand curve for Hamburger Helper.
a movement down along the demand curve for Hamburger Helper.
an initial movement up and then down along the demand curve for Hamburger Helper.

question: Consider the market for cell phones. Suppose the price of a cell phone falls. Explain the effect of this event on the quantity of cell phones demanded and on the demand for cell phones.

options.answer: The quantity of cell phones demanded is unchanged and the demand for cell phones increases.
The quantity of cell phones demanded decreases and the demand for cell phones is unchanged.
The quantity of cell phones demanded increases and the demand for cell phones is unchanged.
The quantity of cell phones demanded increases and the demand for cell phones also increases.
The quantity of cell phones demanded is unchanged and the demand for cell phones decreases.

question: People buy more of good 1 when the price of good 2 rises. Good 1 and good 2 are

options.answer: complements.
substitutes.
normal goods.
inferior goods.
substitutes in production

question: Oatmeal is a normal good and cold cereal is a substitute for oatmeal. Raisins are a complement of oatmeal. Which of the following increases the demand for oatmeal?

options.answer: an increase in the price of raisins
a decrease in income
a decrease in population
an increase in the price of cold cereal
an increase in the supply of oatmeal

question: The law of supply tells us that other things remaining the same, as the

options.answer: price of gasoline falls, the quantity of gasoline supplied decreases.
price of gasoline rises, the quantity of gasoline supplied decreases.
supply of gasoline increases, the price of gasoline falls.
cost of producing gasoline falls, the supply of gasoline will increase.
cost of producing gasoline increases, the price of gasoline rises.

question: The supply curve of a good slopes upward to the right because of

options.answer: technological improvements over time.
the law of supply.
the law of demand.
the existence of substitutes in production.
the fact that prices tend to rise over time.

question: An increase in supply is shown by

options.answer: a movement down along the supply curve.
a movement up along the supply curve.
a rightward shift of the supply curve.
a leftward shift of the supply curve.
an initial movement up and then down along the same supply curve.

question: If goods X and Y are substitutes in production, then a rise in the price of good X

options.answer: increases the demand for good Y.
decreases the demand for good Y.
increases the supply of good Y.
decreases the supply of good Y.
might change the supply of Y; it depends on whether X and Y are also substitutes.

question: If a producer can use its factors of production to produce either good A or good B, then a rise in the price of A

options.answer: increases the supply of B.
decreases the supply of A.
increases the supply of A.
decreases the supply of B.
both C and D.

question: The fact that a fall in the price of a good results in a decrease in the quantity of the good supplied illustrates

options.answer: the law of supply.
the law of demand.
a change in supply.
the nature of an inferior good.
technological improvement.

question: Which one of the following would not shift the supply curve of good X to the right?

options.answer: a fall in the price of the factors of production used in producing X
an improvement in technology used in the production of X
a rise in the price of X
an increase in the price of Y, a complement in production of X
a fall in the price of Y, a substitute in production of X

question: A decrease in the quantity supplied is shown by a

options.answer: movement down along the supply curve.
movement up along the supply curve.
rightward shift of the supply curve.
leftward shift of the supply curve.
rightward shift of the demand curve.

question: Which one of the following will shift the supply curve of good X leftward?

options.answer: a decrease in the wages of workers employed to produce X
an increase in the cost of machinery used to produce X
a technological improvement in the production of X
a situation where quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied
a decrease in the cost of capital used to produce X

question: Which of the following will shift the supply curve of good X rightward?

options.answer: a decrease in the wages of workers employed to produce good X
an increase in the cost of capital used to produce good X
an increase in the price of energy
a decrease in the number of suppliers of good X
the price of Y, a substitute in production for good X, rises

question: If a factor of production can be used to produce either good A or good B, then A and B are

options.answer: substitutes in production.
complements in production.
substitutes.
complements.
normal goods.

question: A rise in the price of a good

options.answer: decreases demand for the good.
creates a movement up along the supply curve.
creates a movement down along the demand curve.
increases the supply of the good.
increases preferences for the good.

question: If the number of suppliers of good Y increases, then

options.answer: a movement up along the supply curve of good Y will occur.
a movement down along the supply curve of good Y will occur.
the supply curve of good Y shifts rightward.
the supply curve of good Y shifts leftward.
the supply curve of good Y will remain unchanged.

question: A shift of the supply curve for rutabagas occurs if there is

options.answer: a change in preferences for rutabagas.
a change in the price of a related good that is a substitute for rutabagas.
a change in income.
a change in the price of rutabagas.
none of the above.

question: Some producers are chatting over a beer. Which one of the following quotations refers to a movement along the supply curve?

options.answer: "Wage increases have forced us to raise our prices."
"Our new, sophisticated equipment will enable us to undercut our competitors."
"Raw material prices have sky-rocketed; we will have to pass the cost on to our customers."
"We anticipate a big increase in demand. Our product price should rise, so we are planning for an increase in output."
"New competitors in the industry are causing prices to fall."

question: Some producers are chatting over a beer. Which one of the following quotations refers to a rightward shift of the supply curve?

options.answer: "Wage increases have forced us to raise our prices."
"Our new, sophisticated equipment will enable us to undercut our competitors."
"Raw material prices have sky-rocketed; we will have to pass the cost on to our customers."
"We anticipate a big increase in demand. Our product price should rise, so we are planning for an increase in output."
Both A and C.

question: Some producers are chatting over a beer. Which one of the following quotations refers to a leftward shift of the supply curve?

options.answer: "Wage increases have forced us to raise our prices."
"Our new, sophisticated equipment will enable us to undercut our competitors."
"Raw material prices have sky-rocketed; we will have to pass the cost on to our customers."
"We anticipate a big increase in demand. Our product price should rise, so we are planning for an increase in output."
Both A and C.

question: A decrease in the quantity supplied of a good is shown by

options.answer: a movement down along the supply curve.
a leftward shift of the supply curve.
a movement up along the supply curve.
a rightward shift of the supply curve.
an initial rightward shift and then leftward shift of the supply curve.

question: Which of the following decreases the supply of popcorn?

options.answer: a decrease in the price of popcorn
an increase in the price of popcorn
a technological advance in the production of popcorn
a decrease in the demand for popcorn
a decrease in the number of popcorn producers

question: Which of the following shifts the supply curve for good X leftward?

options.answer: a situation in which the quantity demanded of X exceeds the quantity supplied of X
an increase in the cost of the machinery used to produce X
a technological advance in the production of X
a decrease in the wages of workers employed to produce X
a situation in which the quantity supplied of X exceeds the quantity demanded of X

question: Refer to Table 3.4.1. At a price of $3 a unit

options.answer: the market is in equilibrium.
there is a 180-unit surplus.
there is a 180-unit shortage.
there is a tendency for the price to rise.
C and D.

question: In Table 3.4.1, the equilibrium price is

options.answer: $7 a unit.
$5 a unit.
$4 a unit.
$3 a unit.
$1 a unit.

question: In Table 3.4.1, the equilibrium quantity is

options.answer: 200 units.
320 units.
420 units.
500 units.
none of the above; there is no equilibrium.

question: Refer to Table 3.4.1. The equilibrium quantity is 420 units if

options.answer: the price is fixed at $3 a unit.
the price is fixed at $4 a unit.
the price is fixed at $5 a unit.
both A and C are correct.
none of the above.

question: Refer to Table 3.4.1. A shortage occurs if

options.answer: the price is $7 a unit.
the price is $4 a unit.
the price is $5 a unit.
the price is below $4 a unit.
the price is $6 a unit.

question: Refer to Table 3.4.1. A surplus occurs if

options.answer: the price is $2 a unit.
the price is $3 a unit.
the price is above $4 a unit.
the price is $1 a unit.
the price is $4 a unit.

question: Refer to Table 3.4.1. If the price is $7, then the surplus is

options.answer: 360 units.
400 units.
160 units.
zero units.
290 units.

question: Refer to Table 3.4.1. If the price is $3, then the shortage is

options.answer: zero units.
1,050 units.
180 units.
600 units.
160 units.

question: At price P3 in Figure 3.4.1,

options.answer: this market is in equilibrium.
there is a shortage in the amount of Q5 - Q1.
there is a tendency for the price to rise.
equilibrium quantity is Q5.
there is a surplus in the amount of Q5 - Q1.

question: At price P2 in Figure 3.4.1, which one of the following is not true?

options.answer: This market is in equilibrium.
The quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied.
The quantity demanded is Q1.
There is no surplus.
The quantity supplied is Q3.

question: At price P1 in Figure 3.4.1

options.answer: there is a surplus in the amount of Q4 - Q2.
there is a shortage in the amount of Q4 - Q2.
there is a tendency for the price to fall.
the equilibrium quantity is Q2.
the equilibrium quantity is Q4.

question: At price P1 in Figure 3.4.1,

options.answer: producers can sell all they plan to sell.
consumers can buy all they want.
producers are unwilling to sell any goods.
a surplus exists.
both sides of the market are able to carry out their desired transactions.

question: The equilibrium price in the market illustrated by Figure 3.4.2 is

options.answer: $2 a unit.
$4 a unit.
$6 a unit.
$8 a unit.
$10 a unit.

question: Refer to Figure 3.4.2. When the price is $10 a unit

options.answer: consumers will buy only 100 units of output.
consumers will buy 500 units of output.
consumers will buy nothing.
a shortage occurs.
the surplus is zero.

question: At a price of $10 a unit in Figure 3.4.2

options.answer: there is a surplus of 200 units.
there is a shortage of 200 units.
there is a surplus of 400 units.
there is a shortage of 400 units.
quantity will rise.

question: At a price of $4 a unit in Figure 3.4.2

options.answer: the equilibrium quantity is 400 units.
there is a surplus of 200 units.
the quantity supplied is 400 units.
there is a shortage of 200 units.
the quantity demanded is 200 units.

question: Which one of the following correctly describes how price adjustment eliminates a surplus?

options.answer: As the price rises, the quantity demanded decreases and the quantity supplied increases.
As the price rises, the quantity demanded increases and the quantity supplied decreases.
As the price falls, the quantity demanded decreases and the quantity supplied increases.
As the price falls, the quantity demanded increases and the quantity supplied decreases.
As the price falls, the demand for substitutes decreases, which eliminates the surplus.

question: Which one of the following correctly describes how price adjustment eliminates a shortage?

options.answer: As the price rises, the quantity demanded decreases and the quantity supplied increases.
As the price rises, the quantity demanded increases and the quantity supplied decreases.
As the price falls, the quantity demanded decreases and the quantity supplied increases.
As the price falls, the quantity demanded increases and the quantity supplied decreases.
As the price falls, the quantity demanded increases and the quantity supplied increases.

question: If the price is above the equilibrium price, then

options.answer: none of the good will be sold.
the price must rise further to reach the new market equilibrium.
a surplus exists.
a shortage exists.
price will not change; producers will cut back production until the market is in equilibrium.

question: A shortage will exist if

options.answer: the price is above the equilibrium price.
the price is below the equilibrium price.
there are not enough producers.
there are not enough consumers.
demand decreases.

question: The price of a good will tend to fall if

options.answer: there is a surplus at the current price.
the current price is below the equilibrium price.
the quantity supplied exceeds the quantity demanded at the current price.
both A and C are true.
none of the above are true.

question: If the market for Twinkies is in equilibrium, then

options.answer: Twinkies must be a normal good.
producers would like to sell more at the current price.
consumers would like to buy more at the current price.
there is a surplus.
the equilibrium quantity equals the quantity demanded.

question: A shortage is the amount by which quantity

options.answer: demanded exceeds quantity supplied.
supplied exceeds quantity demanded.
demanded increases when the price rises.
demanded exceeds the equilibrium quantity.
supplied exceeds the equilibrium quantity.

question: Complete the following sentence. A surplus

options.answer: exists if the price is above the equilibrium price.
is the amount by which the quantity demanded exceeds the quantity supplied.
is the amount by which the quantity demanded exceeds the equilibrium quantity.
is the amount by which the quantity supplied exceeds the equilibrium quantity.
will lead to rising prices.

question: When a shortage occurs, there is a tendency for the

options.answer: price to fall.
price to remain unchanged.
price to rise.
quantity demanded to increase.
quantity supplied to decrease.

question: Refer to Table 3.4.2. The table shows the demand and supply schedules for shampoo. If the price is $6 a bottle, there is a ________ of shampoo. So the price of a bottle of shampoo ________, the quantity demanded ________ and the quantity supplied ________. The market moves to equilibrium.

options.answer: shortage; rises; decreases; increases
shortage; falls; decreases; increases
surplus; rises; increases; decreases
surplus; falls; increases; decreases
shortage; rises; increases; decreases

question: If the quantity of textbooks supplied is 10,000 per year and the quantity of textbooks demanded is 8,000 per year, there is a ________ in the market and the price will ________.

options.answer: shortage; rise
shortage; fall
surplus; rise
surplus; fall
surplus; either rise or fall depending on whether supply increases to meet the surplus

question: If the market for Twinkies is in equilibrium, then

options.answer: Twinkies must be a normal good.
producers would like to sell more at the current price.
consumers would like to buy more at the current price.
the quantity supplied equals the quantity demanded.
the supply of Twinkies will never increase and the demand for Twinkies will never decrease.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Since 1980, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of working mothers. Based on this information alone, we can predict that the market for child care services has experienced

options.answer: an increase in demand.
a decrease in demand.
an increase in quantity demanded.
a decrease in quantity supplied.
an increase in supply.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If the demand curve is D2 in Figure 3.5.1,

options.answer: the equilibrium price is P2 and the equilibrium quantity is Q2.
the equilibrium price is P2 and the equilibrium quantity is Q0.
there is a shortage in the amount of Q2 â Q0.
a rise in price will shift the demand curve to D3.
price will rise.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Initially, the demand curve for good A is D2 in Figure 3.5.1. Suppose good B is a substitute for good A. If the price of B falls

options.answer: the price of A will rise.
there will be a surplus of good A at P2.
the demand curve for good A will shift from D2 to D3.
the equilibrium quantity of good A will increase.
all of the above are true except B.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Initially, the demand curve for good A is D2 in Figure 3.5.1. If income increases and A is a normal good, we would expect to see a movement from point A to point

options.answer: B.
C.
D.
E.
C and back to point A.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: The price of a good will rise if

options.answer: demand for the good decreases.
supply of the good decreases.
there is a surplus of the good.
the price of a substitute for the good decreases.
the good is an inferior good and income increases.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: The price of a good will fall if

options.answer: there is a shortage of the good.
if demand for the good increases.
there is a surplus of the good.
if the supply of the good decreases.
if demand for the good does not change.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: The price of a good will fall if

options.answer: demand for the good increases.
supply of the good decreases.
supply of the good increases.
demand for the good remains constant.
supply of the good remains constant.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Suppose we observe a rise in the price of good A and an increase in the quantity of good A bought and sold. Which one of the following is a likely explanation?

options.answer: The law of demand is violated.
The demand for A decreased.
The demand for A increased.
The supply of A increased.
The supply of A decreased.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Suppose we observe a rise in the price of good A and a decrease in the quantity of good A bought and sold. Which one of the following is a likely explanation?

options.answer: The law of supply is violated.
The demand for A decreased.
The demand for A increased.
The supply of A increased.
The supply of A decreased.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Suppose we observe a fall in the price of good A and an increase in the quantity of good A bought and sold. Which one of the following is a likely explanation?

options.answer: The law of supply is violated.
The demand for A decreased.
The demand for A increased.
The supply of A increased.
The supply of A decreased.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Suppose we observe a fall in the price of good A and a decrease in the quantity of good A bought and sold. Which one of the following is a likely explanation?

options.answer: The law of demand is violated.
The demand for A decreased.
The demand for A increased.
The supply of A increased.
The supply of A decreased.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: When the demand for good A increases,

options.answer: the equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity will increase.
the equilibrium price will rise but the equilibrium quantity will decrease.
the equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity will decrease.
the equilibrium price will decrease but the equilibrium quantity will increase.
a surplus will result.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: When the supply of good A decreases,

options.answer: the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity will increase.
the equilibrium price will increase but the equilibrium quantity will decrease.
the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity will decrease.
the equilibrium price will decrease but the equilibrium quantity will increase.
a surplus will result.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If A is an inferior good and consumer income rises, the demand for A

options.answer: increases and the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity increase.
increases and the equilibrium price rises but the equilibrium quantity decreases.
decreases and the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity decrease.
decreases and the equilibrium price falls but the equilibrium quantity increases.
decreases and the equilibrium price rises; as a result, the equilibrium quantity decreases.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If A and B are substitutes and the price of A rises, we will observe

options.answer: an increase in the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity of B.
a decrease in the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity of B.
an increase in the equilibrium price but a decrease in the equilibrium quantity of B.
a decrease in equilibrium price but an increase in the equilibrium quantity of B.
none of the above.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If A and B are substitutes and the cost of a factor of production used in the production of A increases, then the price of

options.answer: B falls but the price of A rises.
B rises but the price of A falls.
A falls, and the price of B will stay unchanged.
A and B fall.
A and B rise.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If A and B are substitutes in production and the price of A falls, the supply of B

options.answer: increases and the price of B rises.
increases and the price of B falls.
decreases and the price of B falls.
decreases and the price of B rises.
does not change.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If A and B are complements in production and the price of A falls, the supply of B

options.answer: increases and the price of B rises.
increases and the price of B falls.
decreases and the price of B falls.
decreases and the price of B rises.
does not change.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Crude oil is a very important factor of production used in the production of gasoline. If the price of crude oil rises, we would expect the

options.answer: price of gasoline to rise due to an increase in demand.
price of gasoline to fall due to an increase in demand.
price of gasoline to rise due to a decrease in supply.
equilibrium quantity of gasoline to fall due to an increase in supply.
equilibrium quantity of gasoline to rise due to an increase in demand.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If demand increases and supply decreases, then the

options.answer: equilibrium quantity increases but the effect on the equilibrium price is unknown.
equilibrium quantity decreases but the effect on the equilibrium price is unknown.
equilibrium price falls but the effect on the equilibrium quantity is unknown.
equilibrium price rises but the effect on the equilibrium quantity is unknown.
effect on both equilibrium price and quantity is unknown.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If demand decreases and supply increases, then the

options.answer: equilibrium quantity increases but the effect on the equilibrium price is unknown.
equilibrium quantity decreases but the effect on the equilibrium price is unknown.
equilibrium price falls but the effect on equilibrium quantity is unknown.
equilibrium price rises but the effect on equilibrium quantity is unknown.
effect on both equilibrium price and quantity is unknown.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If we observe a rise in the equilibrium price of good A, we know that either the demand for A has

options.answer: increased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
increased or the supply of A has increased or both.
decreased or the supply of A has increased or both.
decreased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
none of the above.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If we observe a fall in the equilibrium price of good A, we know that either the demand for A has

options.answer: increased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
increased or the supply of A has increased or both.
decreased or the supply of A has increased or both.
decreased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
none of the above.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If we observe an increase in the equilibrium quantity of good A, we know that

options.answer: either the demand for A has increased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
either the demand for A has increased or the supply of A has increased or both.
either the demand for A has decreased or the supply of A has increased or both.
either the demand for A has decreased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
none of the above.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If we observe a decrease in the equilibrium quantity of good A, we know that

options.answer: either the demand for A has increased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
either the demand for A has increased or the supply of A has increased or both.
either the demand for A has decreased or the supply of A has increased or both.
either the demand for A has decreased or the supply of A has decreased or both.
none of the above.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Which of the following will definitely result in an increase in the equilibrium price?

options.answer: an increase in both demand and supply
a decrease in both demand and supply
an increase in demand combined with a decrease in supply
a decrease in demand combined with an increase in supply
an increase in supply combined with a decrease in demand

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Which one of the following will definitely lower the equilibrium price?

options.answer: an increase in both demand and supply
a decrease in both demand and supply
an increase in demand combined with a decrease in supply
a decrease in demand combined with an increase in supply
a decrease in supply combined with an increase in demand

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Which one of the following will definitely decrease the equilibrium quantity?

options.answer: an increase in both demand and supply
a decrease in both demand and supply
an increase in demand combined with a decrease in supply
a decrease in demand combined with an increase in supply
none of the above

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: A technological improvement in the production of good A

options.answer: decreases the supply of A.
increases the demand for A.
decreases the equilibrium price of A and decreases the equilibrium quantity.
decreases the quantity demanded of A.
increases the supply of A.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Which of the following events leads to a rise in the price of oranges?

options.answer: a rise in the price of apples if apples and oranges are substitutes
a scientific discovery that oranges cause hair loss
a decrease in income if oranges are a normal good
good growing weather in Florida
a technological improvement in the production of oranges

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If A and B are complements and the cost of a factor of production used in the production of A decreases, then the price of

options.answer: both A and B will rise.
both A and B will fall.
A will fall and the price of B will rise.
A will rise and the price of B will fall.
A will fall and the price of B will remain unchanged.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If both demand and supply increase, then the equilibrium price

options.answer: and equilibrium quantity increases.
falls but the equilibrium quantity increases.
could either rise or fall, but the equilibrium quantity increases.
rises and the equilibrium quantity could either increase or decrease.
falls and the equilibrium quantity could either increase or decrease.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: There have been severe problems in the Atlantic fishing industry, with large falls in the fish stocks. As a result,

options.answer: the price of fish will fall.
the quantity of fish sold will increase as fishermen will catch more to make up for the shortage.
the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity will fall or rise depending on how large the fall in fish stocks.
both the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity will rise, as consumers will desire even more fish, because they are scarce.
the fall in the fish stocks will lead to a shortage, and a rise in the equilibrium price and a decrease in the equilibrium quantity.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: There have been severe falls in the fish stocks in the Atlantic fishing industry. As a result, we would expect

options.answer: an increase in the demand for meat (e.g., beef), because meat is a complement of fish.
a fall in the price of fish, leading to a decrease in the demand for meat, because meat and fish are substitutes.
a fall in the price of fish, leading to an increase in the demand for meat, because meat and fish are substitutes.
an increase in the demand for meat, because meat is a substitute for fish.
a rise in the price of fish, leading to a decrease in the demand for meat, because meat and fish are complements.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: If Canadians suddenly develop a strong urge to escape the cold winter by taking vacations in Hawaii, the

options.answer: price of a vacation in Hawaii rises and the quantity demanded of Hawaiian vacations decreases.
price of a skiing vacation in the mountains rises.
initial result of the change is a surplus of vacations in Hawaii, leading to a price rise.
price of airline tickets falls as ticket agents make deals in response to this change.
price of luggage will rise, because luggage and vacations are complements.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: The Genius Software Company has developed an amazing new software package to be used only with Einstein Computers. As a result, the equilibrium price of

options.answer: all computers rises.
rival software packages falls leading to an overall increase in the equilibrium quantity of these packages.
all software packages rises.
Einstein computers rises, accompanied by an increase in the equilibrium quantity.
Einstein computers rises, leading to a decrease in the equilibrium quantity.

decrease the price and the quantity demanded of coffee.
decrease the price and the quantity supplied of coffee.
cause none of the above.

decrease the price and the quantity demanded of coffee.

increases, decreases, or remains the same depending on the relative shifts of the demand and supply curves.

decreases.

increases or decreases depending on the relative shifts of the supply and demand curves.

question: Refer to Fact 3.5.1. The price of cream falls. Simultaneously, there is an increase in the wages of farm workers who harvest coffee beans. The equilibrium quantity of coffee

options.answer: increases.
decreases.
remains the same.
increases or decreases depending on the slope of the supply and demand curves.
increases, decreases, or remains the same depending on the relative shifts of the supply and demand curves.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: Refer to Fact 3.5.1. A new study comes out, revealing that drinking Pepsi increases your ability to study. The equilibrium quantity of coffee

options.answer: increases.
decreases.
remains the same.
increases or decreases depending on the slope of the supply and demand curves.
increases or decreases depending on the relative shifts of the supply and demand curves.

options.answer: demand for corn increases.

demand for corn decreases.
supply of corn decreases.

question: When the price of good A rises, the supply curve of good B shifts rightward. Which of the following statements are true?

options.answer: A and B are substitutes.

A is a factor used in the production of B.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: "As domestic car prices have increased, consumers have found foreign cars to be a better bargain. Consequently, domestic car sales have fallen and foreign car sales have risen." Based on this information alone, there has been a

options.answer: shift in the demand curves for both domestic and foreign cars.
shift in the supply curves for both domestic and foreign cars.
movement along the demand curves for both domestic and foreign cars.
movement along the demand curve for domestic cars and a shift of the demand curve for foreign cars.
shift of the demand curve for domestic cars and a movement along the demand curve for foreign cars.

options.answer: substitutes.

options.answer: substitutes in Region 1 and complements in Region 2.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: "As fewer people buy computers, the demand for Internet service will decrease and the price of Internet service will increase. The rise in the price of Internet service will increase the supply of Internet service." This statement is ________ because ________.

options.answer: false; the decrease in the demand for Internet service creates a surplus and to eliminate the surplus, supply increases
true; when the demand for Internet service increases, the supply of Internet service increases so that the price of Internet service does not increase
true, when the demand for Internet service increases, the supply of Internet service increases too so that no surplus occurs
true; the increase in the price of Internet service increases the supply of Internet service to eliminate the shortage
false; a decrease in demand for Internet service does not increase the price of Internet service and an increase in the price of Internet service does not increase the supply of Internet service

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question:
The following events occur one at a time:

I.	The price of crude oil rises.
II.	The price of a car rises.
III.	All speed limits on highways are abolished.
IV.	Robots cut car production costs.

The quantity of gasoline supplied ________.

options.answer: increases when all speed limits on highways are abolished
increases when the price of crude oil rises
decreases when robots cut car production costs
increases when the price of a car rises
decreases when the price of crude oil rises

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: What will happen to the equilibrium price and quantity of coffee if it is discovered to help prevent colds and, at the same time, Brazil and Vietnam emerge in the global market as massive producers of coffee?

options.answer: The equilibrium price will fall and the effect on the equilibrium quantity is uncertain.
The equilibrium price will rise and the effect on the equilibrium quantity is uncertain.
The equilibrium quantity will decrease and the equilibrium price will rise.
The equilibrium quantity will increase and the equilibrium price will remain unchanged.
The equilibrium quantity will increase and the effect on the equilibrium price is uncertain.

topic.name: Predicting Changes in Price and Quantity

question: All shredded wheat producers have decided to add a new ingredient, the "crunch enhancer" to shredded wheat. Crunch enhancer keeps cereals crisper longer in milk and, as a result, consumers decide they like shredded wheat more than before. What happens to the supply and demand curves for shredded wheat now that it costs more to produce and consumers like it better?

options.answer: The supply and demand curves both shift rightward.
The supply curve shifts rightward and the demand curve remains unchanged.
The supply curve shifts leftward and the demand curve shifts rightward.
The supply curve shifts leftward and the demand curve remains unchanged.
Neither curve changes but a movement occurs up along the demand curve and a movement occurs up along the supply curve.

question: The demand curve for knobs is P = 75 - 6QD and the supply curve for knobs is P = 35 + 2QS. What is the equilibrium price of a knob?

options.answer: None of the above.

options.answer: 1,300; zero
